item.title: Agents and the Work-to-Signal Ratio
item.description:
Agents and the Work-to-Signal Ratio

Think about the last time you researched something for work. Not the moment you understood it. The hours before that moment. The Googling. The opening of fourteen tabs. The copying of relevant paragraphs into a document. The reformatting. The rewriting so it sounded like you and not like a Wikipedia article. The making of a chart because someone on the team “needs to see the visual.” The uploading, the linking, the publishing.

item.title: Eighteen Months to What, Exactly?
item.description: Microsoft’s AI chief says white-collar work will be automated in 18 months. Economists see jobless growth. Workers are already pivoting. The real question isn’t whether the grind disappears. It’s what replaces it.

item.title: How Agents Break the Procrastination Loop
item.description: Procrastination isn’t laziness. It’s task aversion, driven by the friction between knowing what you want and actually starting. Agentic AI collapses that friction, and what’s left is the work you actually want to do.

item.title: The Invisible Admissions Office
item.description: Students are asking ChatGPT where to go to college. If your institution isn’t showing up in those answers, you might as well not exist.

item.title: The Grind Is Ending Faster Than You Think
item.description: Microsoft’s AI chief says 18 months. Capgemini is betting €700 million. UC enrollment is shifting. The signals are converging.
